docs.lead_paragraph: When the health bill was being debated in Congress, there was no stronger opponent to it than Senator Tom Coburn, the physician and  Republican from Oklahoma who is known in some circles as Dr. No. In December he said that seniors would die faster because of cuts in Medicare in the version of the health care measure then being considered.

headline.main: BlogTalk: Dr. No, Nancy Pelosi and Fox News

docs.abstract: Senator Tom Coburn, the physician and Republican from Oklahoma, took on Fox News this week.
docs.snippet: Senator Tom Coburn, the physician and Republican from Oklahoma, took on Fox News this week.

docs.lead_paragraph: Prepared for the Big One? Not Exactly | As residents on both sides of the Mexican border cleaned up after Sunday's earthquake, the authorities warned that many Californians remained unprepared for a serious quake, and emergency officials said that budget cuts have strained their ability to handle a disaster. The budget challenges faced by firefighters and other first responders have probably affected preparedness, fire officials say, particularly in remote or lightly populated areas that often depend on larger cities or agencies for help in emergencies. Sunday's quake registered 7.2 and centered in a largely unpopulated area of northern Mexico. But a recent study by the California Emergency Management Agency found a majority of the state's households failing to meet recommendations for many basic emergency needs, like stockpiling water (a minimum of three gallons per person), reinforcing their homes and making disaster plans. "We know that there's going to be an earthquake, and we know it's going to be a major natural disaster," said Lou Paulson, president of the California Professional Firefighters and a captain in the Contra Costa County fire protection district. "And I don't want to be one of the people who stands in front of the state of California and says, 'We told you so.' " [The New York Times]

headline.main: Sampler: Lack of Attention for Earthquake Preparations, and More Attention for 'Story of Stuff '

docs.lead_paragraph: Ever since he ran Bill Clinton's ''It's the Economy, Stupid'' presidential campaign in 1992, James Carville has held a reputation for common-sense Democratic strategy. In recent years, Mr. Carville has seized on the transformation of America's energy system, which simultaneously touches voter concerns about the economy, national security and the environment. But he acknowledges that ''energy independence'' has lately lost political altitude.

headline.main: Drilling Plan May Buoy Efforts on Energy Policy

docs.lead_paragraph: A judge in California dismissed a lawsuit on Thursday that would have barred the American International Group from moving any assets out of that state until an independent audit could verify the company's financial condition, The New York Times's Mary Williams Walsh reported Saturday.

headline.main: Bid to Keep A.I.G. Assets in California Is Dismissed
